Fig. 1 Dependences of catalytic performances of Ag(5 %)/SiC on reaction time (a), temperature (b) and O2 pressure (c), and the comparison of different Ag-loaded catalysts under optimal reaction condition (d). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TEM image (a) and high-resolution TEM image (b) of Ag(5 %)/SiC catalyst. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XPS spectra (a) and XPS Auger spectra (b) of Ag(5 %)/SiC catalyst. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 EPR spectra of Ag(5 %)/SiC catalyst. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Desorption curves of styrene adsorbed on SiC and Ag(5 %)/SiC. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 In-situ FTIR spectra of styrene adsorbed on SiC and Ag(5 %)/SiC. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 The adsorption configurations (side view) of styrene on Si-terminated SiC (a), C-terminated SiC (b) and Ag surface (c). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Proposed reaction mechanism of styrene epoxidation on Ag/SiC. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Recycle stability of Ag(5 %)/SiC catalyst in the styrene epoxidation. SiC supported Ag catalysts were prepared by an impregnation-reduction method for styrene epoxidation in O2 atmosphere. Under the condition of 100 °C, 0.5 MPa O2 and 4 h, 5 wt% Ag/SiC catalyst achieved styrene conversion of 98.5 % and styrene oxide selectivity of 69.7 %. Further studies show that O2 was activated on the Ag surface and then formed reactive oxygen species, 1O2 and •O2 -. Based on the O2 adsorption results, the atomic ratio of O/Ag larger than 0.5 indicated that more oxygen species had spilled over to the SiC surface. In-situ diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and Density Functional Theory calculation results showed that styrene was adsorbed on the SiC surface. The active oxygen species generated on the Ag surface could spill over to the SiC surface, reacting with the adsorbed styrene to produce styrene oxide or benzaldehyde. In addition, the catalyst exhibits good stability. Graphical Abstract Keywords Ag/SiC catalyst Styrene epoxidation Active oxygen species Oxygen spillover Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Styrene oxide (SO) is an important chemical intermediate for producing perfumes, epoxy resins, drugs, sweeteners and others [1]. Traditionally, SO was mainly produced through the dehydrochlorination of styrene chlorohydrin with a base or by oxidizing styrene with organic peracids [2,3]. However, these methods suffer from issues such as environmental pollution, equipment corrosion and poor selectivity. Recently, the catalytic epoxidation of styrene has gained increasing attention as it is a green and energy-efficient route to prepare SO. H2O2, tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP), and O2 have been used as oxidants in the catalytic epoxidation of styrene [4,5]. Among them, O2 is regarded as the most ideal oxidant for the reaction because it is non-toxic, non-corrosive, low-cost and pollution-free. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop highly efficient heterogeneous catalysts for styrene epoxidation in O2 atmosphere. In recent years, researchers have developed various catalysts aimed at achieving the catalytic epoxidation of styrene under O2 atmosphere [6–10]. Rahman et al. reported that indium oxide nanoparticles dispersed on mesoporous silica could activate molecular O₂ and produce SO with a selectivity of 60 % and a conversion of approximately 25 % [11]. Brown et al. prepared a MOF-525-Mn catalyst, which converted styrene to styrene oxide with a yield of 82.8 % [12]. Jiang et al. developed a Co/TS-1 catalyst for the epoxidation reaction in O2 atmosphere and achieved a styrene conversion of 94.5 % and a SO selectivity of 74.3 % at 100 °C [13]. Tian et al. reported a single-atomic-site Ag catalyst supported by mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride, which exhibited a styrene conversion of 96 % and a SO selectivity of 81 % at 100 °C under O2 atmosphere [14]. The epoxidation reaction of alkenes is strongly exothermic, and the heat released in the reaction easily accumulates on the catalytically active sites, leading to a rapid temperature rise of the active sites [15]. Hence, the supported metal particles, especially silver particles, are prone to sintering or aggregation during the process. Therefore, the carriers with good chemical stability and thermal conductivity are desired. Silicon carbide (SiC) is a non-oxide semiconductor with excellent electrical and thermal conductivity, making it a suitable carrier for epoxidation reactions [16,17]. Additionally, some reactants such as nitrobenzene, nitriles, and cinnamic aldehyde are easily adsorbed and activated by the surface of SiC, making it a promising support material in catalysis [18–20]. In this work, we employed a high specific surface area SiC as the carrier and successfully prepared highly dispersed Ag/SiC catalysts. A 5 wt% catalyst can efficiently catalyze the epoxidation of styrene to SO in O2, and achieve a styrene conversion of 98.5 % and a SO selectivity of 69.7 % at 100 °C. Further studies suggest that styrene is adsorbed on the SiC surface and then it reacts with the active oxygen species spilling over from Ag particles. Additionally, the catalyst also shows good stability. 2 Experimental sections 2.1 Catalyst preparation Powder-like SiC carrier with a specific surface area of 68 m2/g was purchased from ReginTech, which was prepared by the carbothermal reduction of a carbonaceous silica xerogel [21]. The SiC carrier was treated with a mixture of HCl and HF to remove possible metals, oxides and other impurities before use. The preparation of 5 wt% Ag/SiC catalyst was described as follows. Firstly, 0.85 g of SiC was dispersed in 30 mL of anhydrous ethanol, and the suspension was magnetically stirred for 10 min. Then, 5 mL of AgNO3 solution (0.046 M) was added dropwise into the suspension under stirring. After 2 h stirring, the mixture was transferred to a rotary evaporator to get a solid AgNO3 and SiC mixture. Next, the solid mixture was transferred to a porcelain boat and calcined at 400 °C for 4 h in air atmosphere. After cooling to room temperature, the catalyst of 5 wt% Ag/SiC was obtained, which was marked as Ag(5 %)/SiC. Similarly, Ag(1 %)/SiC, Ag(3 %)/SiC and Ag(7 %)/SiC catalysts can be prepared by the similar process. 2.2 Catalyst test The epoxidation reaction of styrene was carried out in a 50 mL stirred-tank reactor equipped with heating and magnetic stirring functions. In a typical reaction, 4 mmol of styrene, 150 mg of Ag(5 %)/SiC catalyst, 15 mL of 1,4-dioxane, and 0.5 MPa of oxygen were sealed in the reactor. The reaction liquid was stirred by magnetic agitation (rotation speed at 500 r/min) during the reaction. The mixture was heated (at a rate of 5 °C /min) to 100 °C. After 4 hours of reaction, the filtrate was obtained through the Millipore filter (pore size 0.22 μm). The filtrate and methanol were diluted in a ratio of 1:100. Finally, gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS, Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010 SE) was used for analysis. Detailed chromatographic methods of analysis are given in the Supporting Information. The styrene conversion rate, SO selectivity, SO yield, and turnover frequency (TOF) were calculated using formulas (1)-(4): (1) Conversion = Initial mole number − Final mole number Initial mole number × 100 % # (2) Selectivity = mole number of product mole number of all products × 100 % # (3) Yield = Conversion × Selectivity# (4) TOF = Moles of styrene oxide formed m × w Ag × D Ag × reaction time / M Ag # where m is the mass of the Ag/SiC catalyst, w Ag is the mass fraction of Ag in the catalyst, D Ag is the dispersion degree of Ag on the catalyst surface, and M[Ag] is the relative atomic mass of Ag. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The structure and morphology of the Ag/SiC catalysts were characterized by powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD, D/MAX 2500PC) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI Talos F200x G2, 200 kV). The valence state of Ag was determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fischer ESCALAB Xi +) and XPS Auger spectroscopy, and the values of binding energy were corrected by the C1s peak (284.8 eV) [22]. The ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy was measured using a spectrophotometer (UV–vis, UV-2600i). The reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the reaction system were determined using electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy (EPR, Bruker EMX PLUS). The oxygen adsorption capacity and Ag dispersion were tested by a multifunctional atomic adsorption instrument (Xianquan, TP-5080D). The adsorption of styrene was studied by using the Xianquan adsorption instrument and in-situ diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (In-situ FTIR, Nicolet IS 50). The activation of O₂ on the catalyst surface was studied by in-situ Raman spectroscopy (In-situ Raman, Alpha300R, WITec GmbH). The In-situ Raman analysis was performed using a confocal Raman microscope. The microscope was equipped with a TEM single-frequency laser (λ = 532 nm, laser power = 40 mW). The adsorption energies of styrene on SiC and Ag surfaces were calculated by density functional theory (DFT). 2.4 Styrene adsorption determination Firstly, 0.3 g of powder sample were loaded into the adsorption instrument, and then the sample was pretreated at 650 °C under a N2 flow (30 mL/min) for 1 hour to remove possible impurities. Subsequently, 1 mL of styrene was added to the pretreated sample. After the styrene was fully adsorbed on the sample surface (about 30 minutes), it was purged by N2 (30 mL/min) to get a stable baseline. Then the temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) began at 40 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The In-situ FTIR was employed to determine the adsorption of styrene on the catalyst surface. The sample was firstly pretreated at 200 °C in Ar for 30 minutes, and then three drops (approximately 0.3 mL) of styrene were added. After the sample was purged in Ar (50 mL/min) for 30 minutes, the vacuum system was turned on and the vacuum degree was remained about 10 Pa until the measurement was completed. 2.5 In-situ Raman test The In-situ Raman test was carried out as follows: the sample was pretreated for 30 min at 120 °C under an Ar gas flow (30 mL/min). After cooling to room temperature, the gas flow was switched from Ar to O2 (30 mL/min), and the sample was heated at a rate of 5 °C/min to 100 °C for 1 h. Then, Raman tests were conducted at 25, 50, 75, and 100 °C, and the tests were also conducted at 100 °C for 0.5 and 1 h. 2.6 The control experiment of styrene adsorption The control experiments were carried out as follows: (1) 500 mg of the SiC carrier was soaked in a mixed solution containing 0.5 mL of styrene and 10 mL of ethanol for 1 hour. Then, the SiC solid was filtered out and dried at 40 °C for 5 hours. After this treatment, only adsorbed styrene remained on the SiC surface, and the sample was named as styrene/SiC. (2) 5 mg of the catalyst was thoroughly mixed with 10, 30, 50, 70, and 100 mg of styrene/SiC, respectively, and placed in a steel reactor. Subsequently, 0.5 MPa of H2 or O2 was pressured into the reactor, and the temperature was maintained at 100 °C for 4 h to ensure the adsorbed styrene was completely converted. Lastly, 2 mL of ethanol was added to the reactor and ultrasonicated for 10 minutes to extract any possible reaction products. The product was analyzed using GC-MS. 2.7 O2 adsorption capacity and O/Ag ratio calculations The O2 adsorption capacity was measured as follows: 0.1 g of Ag/SiC catalyst was placed in the adsorption instrument and treated in a N2 flow of 30 mL/min at 400 °C for 1 hour to remove possible adsorbed impurities, and then naturally cooled to 40 °C. Next, the O2 adsorption capacity was measured by using the pulse adsorption method. The dispersion of Ag was determined using a similar method: 0.1 g of catalyst was pretreated and then cooled to 40 °C for H2 pulse adsorption. The H2 adsorption capacity was measured, and the dispersion of Ag was calculated. The O/Ag atomic ratio was calculated using the following formula (5): (5) O / Ag = n O n Ag = q O 2 × m × 2 m × w Ag × D Ag / 107.9 = 215.8 × q O 2 w Ag × D Ag # where n O and n Ag represent the moles of O and Ag atoms, respectively. q O 2 is the O2 adsorption capacity, m is the mass of the Ag/SiC catalyst, w Ag is the mass fraction of Ag in the catalyst, and D Ag is the dispersion degree of Ag on the catalyst surface. 2.8 DFT calculations DFT calculations in this work were carried out using the CP2K package version-2022.1 with Gaussian Plane Wave (GPW) method implemented in the QUICKSTEP module [23]. Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [24] exchange-correlation (XC) functional with Grimme-D3 [25,26] dispersion correction method was employed. Both the double-zeta valence polarized (DZVP) sets and Goedecker-Teter-Hutter (GTH) pseudopotentials were adopted [27–29]. Plane wave and relative cut-offs were set to 400 and 55 Ry, respectively. The inner and outer SCF convergence criteria were set to 1.0 × 10−6 Ha. The SiC (1 1 1) and Ag (1 1 1) surfaces were simulated using slab models with 3 × 3 (18.47 Å × 18.47 Å) and 5 × 5 (14.45 Å × 14.45 Å) surface unit cell periodicity, respectively. In order to avoid interactions between periodic images, a vacuum distance of 20 Å was imposed between different layers. The geometrical optimizations were implemented at the Γ point for all surface structures, with all the atoms being relaxed. Root mean square and maximum force convergence were set to 3.0 × 10−4 and 4.5 × 10−4 Ha·Å−1, respectively. The adsorption energies were calculated according to the following equation: (6) E ads = E slab + adsorbate − E slab − E adsorbate # where E slab + adsorbate , E slab , and E adsorbate are the calculated electronic energy of species adsorbed on the surface, the bare surface, and the gas-phase molecule, respectively. 3 Results and discussion The influences of reaction conditions on the catalytic performances of the Ag(5 %)/SiC catalyst for styrene epoxidation were investigated. Fig. 1(a) shows the performances of the catalyst at 0.5 MPa and 100 °C for different reaction times. From the figure, the styrene conversion gradually increased with the reaction time and reached 98.5 % at 4 hours. However, when the reaction time exceeded 4 h, the selectivity of SO decreased slightly, and the proportion of benzaldehyde (BAL) as a by-product increased. When the reaction time was 0.5 h, the product was mainly BAL. This may be due to O₂ being first transformed into superoxide anion radical (•O2 -) on Ag surface, which then further react with styrene to produce BAL [30]. Therefore, the best performance was achieved at a reaction time of 4 hours. To study the effects of reaction temperature and O2 pressure on the styrene conversion and SO selectivity, the reaction time was selected as 1 h to ensure a middle level of styrene conversion. The effect of reaction temperature is shown in Fig. 1(b). No product was observed at 70 °C, this is because the oxygen needs to be activated at ∼75 °C (Fig.S1). The styrene conversion and the SO selectivity were very low when the temperature increased to 80 °C and 90 °C. Both the conversion and selectivity increased rapidly at 100 °C, indicating that styrene could be effectively converted to SO at 100 °C. This is consistent with the reported work [14]. Fig. 1(c) shows the effect of O2 pressure on the styrene conversion and SO selectivity at 100 °C. As the O2 pressure increased from 0.1 MPa to 1 MPa, the conversion gradually increased to ∼ 55 % and then slightly decreased, while the SO selectivity consistently showed a downward trend. When the O2 pressure was 0.3 MPa and 0.5 MPa, the yields of SO were 24.6 % and 33.5 %, respectively (corresponding TOF were 30 h−1 and 40.8 h−1, respectively). Therefore, the O2 pressure of 0.5 MPa is suitable for the reaction. In addition, some other by-products (benzoic acid, 1-Phenyl-1,2-ethanediol and acetophenone) are present in the reaction, and their overall selectivity is less than ∼5 %. These by-products are common in styrene epoxidation reactions [31,32]. Under the optimal conditions, 0.5 MPa of O2 pressure, 100 °C and 4 h, the catalytic performances of Ag/SiC with different Ag loadings were further investigated, as shown in Fig. 1(d). Without any catalyst, the styrene conversion was approximately 7.8 % and the SO selectivity was 58.6 %, which are similar to the reported in literature [13,33]. In the presence of Ag/SiC catalyst, the styrene conversion increased rapidly. As the Ag loading increased from 1 wt% to 7 wt%, the styrene conversions increased from 18.5 % to 98.5 %, indicating that the Ag/SiC catalysts could effectively catalyze the epoxidation reaction. In the epoxidation reaction, the metallic Ag functions as the active sites to activate oxygen [34]. Obviously, more Ag particles will produce more active Ag surfaces. The number of Ag particles on SiC increases with the Ag loading when the Ag loading is less than 5 wt% (Fig.S2). When the Ag loading exceeds 5 wt%, further continuing increase in Ag loading will lead to an increase in the size of Ag particles, but not an increase in the active Ag surface. So, in this work, the optimal Ag loading was 5 wt%. The turnover frequency (TOF) values for the four catalysts were calculated to be 42.2, 76.4, 83.7, and 73.0 h−1, respectively, and the TOF value of Ag(5 %)/SiC catalyst was the highest. As compared with reported results (Table S1), Ag(5 %)/SiC is a promising catalyst for styrene epoxidation. The morphology and size distribution of Ag particles in Ag(5 %)/SiC catalyst were characterized using TEM, as shown in Fig. 2. From Fig. 2(a), the Ag particles on the SiC surface are uniformly dispersed and have a quasi-spherical morphology. The average size of Ag particles was statistically calculated to be 3.2 nm. Fig. 2(b) presents a high-resolution TEM image of a particle, in which the lattice fringes of the particle can be clearly observed and the lattice spacing is 0.238 nm, corresponding to the (111) crystal plane spacing of Ag [35]. In addition, XRD patterns (Fig.S3) of Ag/SiC catalysts also showed apparent diffraction peaks of β-SiC and Ag. The relatively weak Ag diffraction peaks indicate that the Ag particles are highly dispersed on the support surface [36]. This is also consistent with the TEM results shown in Fig. 2(a). XPS was used to determine the chemical state of Ag in Ag(5 %)/SiC catalyst. Typically, the binding energy (BE) of metallic Ag 3d5/2 is in the range of 367.9–368.5 eV, and the BE of Ag 3d3/2 is in the range of 373.9–375.0 eV [36–38]. Unlike common metals, the BE value of oxidized Ag is usually lower than that of metallic Ag [39]. Fig. 3(a) shows the XPS spectra of Ag 3d region, from which the BEs of Ag 3d5/2 and Ag 3d3/2 are 368.5 eV and 374.5 eV, respectively, indicating that the Ag on the catalyst surface is in a metallic state (Ag0). Since the BEs of metallic and oxidized Ag are similar, XPS Auger spectroscopy was used to further distinguish them. Fig. 3(b) shows the Ag MNN XPS Auger peak of Ag(5 %)/SiC catalyst, in which a significant peak appears at 351.8 eV, indicating that the Ag in Ag(5 %)/SiC is metallic [40]. Similarly, the Ag in Ag(1 %)/SiC, Ag(3 %)/SiC and Ag(7 %)/SiC is also metallic (Fig.S4). The UV–vis spectra of Ag/SiC catalysts were further measured. In the spectra (Fig.S5), obvious protrusions present at around 410 nm, which are caused by the localized surface plasmon resonance of Ag nanoparticles [38], further confirming the existence of metallic Ag nanoparticles. In addition, the SiC carrier is a n-type semiconductor with a bandgap of 2.36 eV [41]. Since the work function of Ag (4.26 eV) is higher than that of SiC (4 eV), the electron transfer can occur from SiC to Ag due to the Mott-Schottky effect, resulting in electron-rich metallic Ag. This is consistent with the XPS results. The adsorption capacity of Ag/SiC catalysts was determined by O2 pulse adsorption. For the Ag(5 %)/SiC catalyst, the measured O2 adsorption capacity was 33.2 μmol/g. Moreover, the O2 adsorption capacity of catalysts gradually increased with the increase of Ag loading (Table S2). This indicates that supported Ag particles can activate O2 [42,43]. The dispersion of Ag in Ag(5 %)/SiC estimated by the H2 pulse adsorption was 0.118, and the further calculated O/Ag atomic ratio was 1.2. The lower the Ag loading, the higher the O/Ag ratio (Table S2). The O/Ag ratios in Ag/SiC catalysts are all larger than 0.5, indicating that most of oxygen species have spilled over to the surface of SiC carrier. The reactive oxygen species on Ag/SiC catalysts in the styrene epoxidation were determined by EPR at 30 min. 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine (TEMP) and 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) were used as capture agents for singlet oxygen(1O2) and •O2 -, respectively. Fig. 4(a) shows the results of TEMP-1O2 test, with a characteristic of 1:1:1 triplet line, confirming the formation of 1O2 in the system [44]. Fig. 4(b) shows the results of DMPO-•O2 - test, with six distinct peaks, four strong and two weak peaks. The four strong peaks exhibit a 1:1:1:1 intensity ratio, confirming the presence of •O2 - radicals [45]. It is established that 1O2 is crucial for the formation of SO while •O2 - primarily lead to the byproduct BAL [30]. Further, the amount of reactive oxygen species was tested on different catalysts, as shown in Table 1. The amounts of both 1O2 and •O2 - increased with the increase of Ag loading. Among them, the content of •O2 - is significantly higher than that of 1O2. This may be related to the activation process of O2. In this work, O2 was first converted to •O2 - and then further transformed to 1O2. After O2 was introduced for 30 min, much of O2 had already been converted to •O2 -, and the transformation of •O2 - to 1O2 was low. Hence, most of the products are BAL when the reaction time is 30 min (Fig. 1(a)). Besides, when the Ag loading increased from 5 wt% to 7 wt%, •O2 - increased rapidly while the 1O2 increased slightly. This is consistent with the performance results in Fig. 1(d). The above results further demonstrate that 1O2 is essential for the formation of SO, while •O2 - primarily leads to the production of BAL. The adsorption of styrene on SiC and Ag(5 %)/SiC were measured by TPD, and the results were shown in Fig. 5. It can be clearly seen that there are two desorption peaks on the two samples. The first desorption peak on SiC appears at about 190 °C, which is slightly higher than the boiling point of styrene (145.2 °C), indicating that the desorption is caused by physically adsorbed styrene. For Ag(5 %)/SiC, the peak shifted to ∼210 °C and its area increased evidently, which may be attributed to the adsorption of styrene on the surface of Ag particles. The second desorption peak appears at about 450 °C, indicating that these styrene molecules are chemisorbed. It is worth noting that the second peak is very similar on both curves, suggesting that the chemical adsorption of styrene may occur mainly on the surface of SiC carrier. In-situ FTIR was used to further verify the adsorption of styrene, and SiC and Ag(5 %)/SiC samples were diluted with KBr (the mass ratio is 1:150) in the measurement. From Fig. 6, the IR spectra of styrene on KBr present a series of adsorption bands. Specifically, the bands at 1681 and 1629 cm−1 can be attributed to the CC stretching vibration of the vinyl group in styrene [31,46], the bands between 1600 and 1500 cm−1 to the stretching vibration of the aromatic CC bond [47], the bands at 1494 and 1449 cm−1 to the phenyl C-C ring extensions [31], and the peak of 1412 cm−1 to the vinyl =CH2 deformation of the styrene molecule [31]. Compared with the spectra of styrene on KBr, the spectra of styrene on SiC and Ag(5 %)/SiC exhibit significant differences. All the absorption bands relative to the vinyl group, 1681, 1629 and 1412 cm−1, show obvious blue shifts to 1685, 1636 and 1420 cm−1, respectively. Other absorption bands at 1540, 1521, 1516, 1488 and 1472 cm−1 are assigned to the skeletal vibrations of aromatic ring [47–49]. In addition, the IR spectra of styrene on SiC and Ag(5 %)/SiC also exhibit visible changes, especially in the range of 1450–1550 cm−1, which may be caused by the presence of Ag particles. From these IR results, it is evident that the chemisorption of styrene on Ag5/SiC occurs mainly on the surface of SiC. In addition, a control experiment was conducted to demonstrate the adsorption of styrene on the SiC surface. 30 mg of the composite of styrene/SiC was mixed with 5 mg Ag(5 %)/SiC as the catalyst for the epoxidation reaction. However, no product was detected under the given conditions. When Ag(5 %)/SiC was replaced by Pt(5 %)/SiC, the hydrogenated product (ethylbenzene) could be found under H2 reaction conditions (Fig.S6). This is because the active hydrogen dissociated from Pt/SiC spills over to styrene/SiC and reacts with adsorbed styrene. In contrast, under O2 reaction conditions, the spillover distance of oxygen species is too short to reach the surface of the styrene/SiC composite. Furthermore, the adsorption energies of styrene on SiC and Ag surfaces were calculated by DFT. DFT calculations in this work were carried out using the CP2K package version-2022.1 [50], and more details can be found elsewhere. Fig. 7 shows the adsorption configurations (side view) of styrene on SiC (111) and Ag (111) surfaces. The calculated adsorption energies were −6.028 eV for Si-terminated SiC, −5.583 eV for C-terminated SiC and −1.906 eV for Ag, respectively. These results indicate that styrene molecules will be preferentially adsorbed on the SiC surface. Generally, the length of the CC bond in styrene is 1.344 Å. After adsorption, the calculated CC bond lengths are 1.486 Å (Si-terminated), 1.507 Å (C-terminated) and 1.373 Å (Ag) respectively, indicating that the CC bond was activated on the SiC surface and participated in the epoxidation reaction. According to the above experimental and calculation results, it is suggested that styrene is adsorbed on SiC surface while O2 is activated on the Ag surface in the epoxidation. Referring to relevant studies on spillover [51,52], a plausible reaction mechanism is proposed for understanding the epoxidation of styrene on Ag/SiC, as shown in Fig. 8. During the reaction, O2 is firstly adsorbed on the Ag surface. These adsorbed O2 molecules can form •O2 - radicals or singlet 1O2, and then spillover to SiC surface. The styrene adsorbed on SiC surface reacts with the spilled •O2 - to produce BAL (route I), or reacts with 1O2 to produce SO (route II). This mechanism differs from common viewpoints, where both O2 and styrene are activated on the Ag surface. Finally, the stability of Ag(5 %)/SiC catalyst was evaluated through recycling experiments, and the results were shown in Fig. 9. After five cycles, the conversion of styrene remained almost unchanged, while the selectivity of SO showed a slightly decrease. TEM characterizations indicate that Ag nanoparticles still remain good dispersion on SiC surface (Fig.S7). However, the mean size of Ag particles has a slight increase from initial 3.2 nm to 3.8 nm. The XPS analysis of the used catalyst shows that Ag⁰ and a small amount of Ag⁺ coexist in the catalyst (Fig.S8). The slight increase in Ag particle size and the minor change of Ag state may lead to the decreasing of SO selectivity. The stability of other carriers supported Ag catalysts were also tested (Fig.S9). Compare with Ag(5 %)/SiC, the epoxidation performance of Ag(5 %)/Al2O3 and Ag(5 %)/SiO2 showed a significant decrease after 3 cycles, and the color of Ag(5 %)/Al2O3 changed significantly (Fig.S10). The above results show that Ag(5 %)/SiC is a promising catalyst for the epoxidation of styrene. 4 Conclusion In summary, we successfully prepared a 5 wt% Ag/SiC catalyst, in which Ag particles were uniformly distributed on SiC surface and had an average size of 3.2 nm. When O2 was used as the oxidant, the styrene conversion and SO selectivity were 98.5 % and 69.7 %, respectively. The catsalyst exhibited good recycle stability due to the excellent thermal conductivity of SiC carrier, which efficiently dispersed the reaction heat. The experimental and computational results showed that in the epoxidation process, O2 was activated on the Ag surface to form 1O2 and •O2 -, which then spilled over to the SiC surface and reacted with the styrene adsorbed on the SiC surface. The present work provides new insight for understanding the epoxidation reaction and helps to the development of epoxidation catalysts. coredata.dc:description: SiC supported Ag catalysts were prepared by an impregnation-reduction method for styrene epoxidation in O2 atmosphere. Under the condition of 100 °C, 0.5 MPa O2 and 4 h, 5 wt% Ag/SiC catalyst achieved styrene conversion of 98.5 % and styrene oxide selectivity of 69.7 %. Further studies show that O2 was activated on the Ag surface and then formed reactive oxygen species, 1O2 and •O2 -. Based on the O2 adsorption results, the atomic ratio of O/Ag larger than 0.5 indicated that more oxygen species had spilled over to the SiC surface. In-situ diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and Density Functional Theory calculation results showed that styrene was adsorbed on the SiC surface. The active oxygen species generated on the Ag surface could spill over to the SiC surface, reacting with the adsorbed styrene to produce styrene oxide or benzaldehyde. In addition, the catalyst exhibits good stability.
